topic.title: HPE Helion OpenStack Community Network Architecture and Configuration - Baremetal Installations Only

titlealts.searchtitle: HPE Helion Openstack Community Network Architecture and Configuration -- Baremetal Installations Only

body.p: This page provides an overview of important information on the network configuration required for a baremetal HPE Helion OpenCloud Community edition installation.

For virtual installations, the installation simulates the deployment of OpenStack by creating and configuring a set of virtual machines (VMs) on a single system. As such, no manual network configuration is required.

li.xref: Network configuration for a baremetal installation

section.title: Physical network architecture
section.p: The table in this section provides an overview of the physical network configuration requirements you must meet, with the following assumptions:

li.p: Physical network ports on each server:

ul.li: One physical ethernet port (for example, eth0) for the hypervisor/OS
Two physical links, one for IPMI/iLO and one for the hypervisor/OS
Network switches capable of basic VLAN, L2 and L3 functions; no dependency on, for example, VxLAN-capable or OpenFlow-enabled switch

li.p: The physical hypervisor/OS network is shared by a number of logical networks, and each logical network has its own VLAN and IP subnet.

ul.li: The seed VM, the baremetal systems, and the BMC (IPMI controller) for all baremetal systems must be on a common network.
Traffic for undercloud internal OpenStack calls, Glance image downloads, etc.
Provides access to undercloud API endpoints
Used to PXE boot overcloud servers

row.entry: Traffic for overcloud internal OpenStack calls, glance image downloads, etc.
Network between workload VMs, e.g. carries VxLAN traffic
iSCSi traffic between VMs and storage products like StoreVirtual

ul.li: Provides access to overcloud API endpoints

row.entry: Communication between swift servers (includes user data)

section.title: Network configuration
section.p: Make sure your network is configured to include the following criteria:

li.p: The seed VM, the baremetal systems and the IPMI controller for all systems must be on the same network.
Any network interfaces that are not used for PXE boot must be disabled from BIOS to prevent PXE boot attempts from those devices.
Any DHCP servers on the same network as your system must not hand out IP addresses to your physical nodes as they PXE boot.

Make sure there is no wildcard DHCP server on your network. The wildcard DHCP server will likely reply to the booting under/overcloud servers before the seed VM, which will cause the PXE boot process to fail.

The network interface intended as the bridge interface should be configured and working before running the installer. The installer creates a network bridge on the system running the installer, attaching the bridge interface to the network bridge. The installer uses the IP address of the bridge interface for the network bridge.
The IPMI/BMC interfaces of the real hardware must be accessible from the seed VM.

section.title: Network defaults
section.p: The installation process includes a number of default configurations. You can change many of these defaults during the installation, using the steps detailed in Community Baremetal Installation and Configuration.

ul.li: The default network configuration uses a single subnet 192.0.2.0/24 for all networking.
The Seed VM is assigned an IP address of 192.0.2.1, in addition to the IP address assigned by the libvirt package.

The external interface of host of the seed VM is added to a software bridge, called brbm, on the host and the IP address of the external interface is transferred to the bridge. This allows external traffic on 192.0.2.0/24 to be routed to the seed VM.
The seed VM is the gateway for all traffic outside the baremetal network.

li.p: IP addresses are assigned by default as follows:

ul.li: 192.0.2.2-192.0.2.20 is used by the seed cloud to administer the undercloud nodes
192.0.2.21-192.0.2.124 is used by the undercloud to administer the overcloud nodes
192.0.2.129-1920.0.2.254 is used as a pool of addresses for floating IPs for the virtual machines in the overcloud.

li.p: The IP address range for the private IPs assigned to new virtual instances is 10.0.0.0/8.

section.title: Changing the default networking configuration
section.p: In the default configuration, the default pool of floating IP addresses for the overcloud is within the baremetal subnet. You can select a different pool of addresses during the installation. If you select a pool of addresses outside the baremetal subnet, make sure those addresses are accessible.

The following example shows how to select a range of IP addresses from 10.23.144.10 to 10.23.151.254 with a subnet mask of 10.23.144.0/21. To avoid overlap with the default private network range of 10.0.0.0/8, OVERCLOUD_FIXED_RANGE_CIDR is changed to 10.0.0.0/16.
During the installation you must set OVERCLOUD_NeutronPublicInterface to the name of the VLAN on which the floating IP addresses will reside (you must create this VLAN separately).

codeblock.codeph: export FLOATING_START=10.23.144.10 export FLOATING_END=10.23.151.254 export FLOATING_CIDR=10.23.144.0/21 export OVERCLOUD_FIXED_RANGE_CIDR=10.0.0.0/16 export OVERCLOUD_NeutronPublicInterface=vlan1515 export NeutronPublicInterfaceRawDevice=eth0 export OVERCLOUD_VIRTUAL_INTERFACE=eth0

section.p: This example assumes a homogeneous overcloud compute hardware.
Important: IP addresses in the ranges chosen for the undercloud and overcloud must not be used by other nodes on your network.
